subject: US MARKET WRAP 11 Jan 2019: US govt shutdown becomes the longest in history
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down/flat, Treasuries up, crude down, dollar up
* REAR-VIEW: CPI in line; Brexit increasingly likely to be delayed; GM raises FY 19 guidance.
* WEEK AHEAD: US retail sales (likely postponed), Brexit vote, UK CPI, retail sales; Canada CPI.

* GOVT SHUTDOWN: Sources cited by Fox News suggested that internal data showed that the impact of shutdown will hit the US economy shortly, as officials grow increasingly worried about economic impact of impasse; Fox also said that US President Trump is likely to end impasse, potentially as soon as next week. Fox News also reported that the White House economic team was divided over attendance at the WEF at the end of the month, with Treasury Secretary Mnuchin planning to attend, though NEC Director Kudlow does not. Later in the session, Trump said he will sign a bill for back pay for Federal workers. Meanwhile, other reports suggest that the OMB has reportedly drafted plans for a government shutdown that runs through February.

* US CPI: December’s inflation report came in line with expectations (headline 1.9% YY, -0.1% MM; core unch at 2.2%, Core MM 0.2% again), with the headline held back by weak gasoline prices, as was expected. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the sharp drop in used auto prices didn’t materialize, adding that CPI measure is hugely overshooting relative to auction prices, so a big drop is coming sooner or later, we just don’t know exactly when. Airline fares fell less than we expected too, down 1.5% m/m; further declines are coming in the wake of the fall in oil prices. The core measure rose broadly, taking the three-month annualised rate to 2.5%, which Pantheon observes is the highest since March. “The run of 0.2% increase in the past three months follows 0.1% Aug/Sep gains, so y/y core inflation has been stuck at 2.2% for the past five straight months. Even if the Dec m/m increase is repeated through Q1 - a tall order given the downward pressure on used auto prices and airline fares - base effects will push the y/y rate down to 2.1% until April.” Looking ahead, the consultancy does not see core rising above the 2.3% seen in July until June this year, unless the run-rate increases. “Tariffs on consumer goods would do that overnight, but we’re expecting the US and China to reach agreement soon to prevent that from happening,” and in the meantime, “the recent core CPI numbers ought to weaken the idea that the US faces meaningful renewed disinflation pressure; we just don’t see that.” Pantheon also cites the recent NFIB survey of selling prices, which I says hints at higher inflation in the second half of 2019, adding that, for now, the numbers are not.

* BREXIT: Ahead of next week’s Meaningful Vote, the Evening Standard reported that Brexit is looking increasingly likely to be delayed beyond March 29th amid a backlog of essential bills, citing Cabinet Ministers; it is worth noting that this is due to technical reasons, rather than a fundamental change of position from the UK. On Friday, a spokesperson for UK PM May once again ruled out an extension to Article 50. There were also reports from BuzzFeed which pointed out that Conservative MEPs have been summoned to Downing Street to meet the PM, and a Number 10 source said it was a regular meeting; however, MEPs speculated that an extension of Article 50 could mean they would have to stand in the European Parliament’s May elections. For a more in depth take on next week’s Brexit vote, see our week in focus (link available at the bottom of this report). Finally, ahead of the vote, UK ministers reportedly have told PM May to seek help from opposition leader Corbyn when Brexit deal is voted down.

* US T-NOTE FUTURE (H19) SETTLS 7+ TICKS HIGHER AT 121-30+: Treasuries firmed on Friday amid the longest US government shutdown in history, as well as reports that the PBOC is becoming wary of yuan strength, while geopolitical headlines also influenced (reports of Turkish troops along the Syrian border). The modest bounce continued after an in-line CPI report, though the complex saw some profit-taking towards the European close, sources noted. Yields were lower across the curve at settlement, with most of the action in the belly, where they fell by around 3bps. Major spreads were mixed, with 2s5s and 2s10s narrowing by around 1bps, while 2s30s and 5s30s steepened by 0.5bps and 2bps respectively.

* WTI (G19) SETTLES $1.00 LOWER AT $51.59; BRENT (H19) SETTLES $1.20 LOWER AT $60.48: Crude futures are looking to snap their impressive run of gains, which had seen WTI's run extend to straight sessions. Without a lot of crude-specific news, the complex was taking its cue from equities, with profit-taking reported once again on Friday. "This looks largely like a minor technical correction rather than a reaction to a shift in the underlying fundamental condition of the markets, although it’s possible the petroleum market reached the limit of how far it could rally in the face of surging US product inventories," Citi said.

* SPX -0.02% at 2596, NDX -0.3% at 6601, DJI -0.04% at 23993. SECTORS: Energy -0.6%, Materials -0.4%, Industrials 0.1%, Cons Discretionary -0.1%, Cons Staples +0.3%, Healthcare ++0.3%, Financials +0.2%, Tech -0.1%, Telecoms -0.1%, Utilities -0.5%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: General Motors (GM) and PVH Corp (PVH) surged on the open after raising their guidance. Infosys (INFY) was a gainer following its earnings report and a share repurchase programme. Netflix (NFLX) opened higher after upgrades at UBS and Raymond James. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) underperformed after it gave publishing rights away for its Destiny franchise. PG&E (PCG) traded lower after its credit rating was downgraded to junk at Moddy’s. Alphabet (GOOGL) opened lower over reports it was being sued by shareholders for keeping sexual misconduct claims hidden. Amazon (AMZN) came under negative light following reports of privacy issues with its Ring smart doorbell and Germany banning its Dash device. Apple (AAPL) moved lower on the open, as new iPhone release details failed to impress investors. Starbucks (SBUX) came under pressure after Goldman downgraded the stock.

* FOREX WEEKLY - DXY: It has been a turbulent week for the Dollar in light of this week’s dovish Fed speakers and FOMC minutes alongside a three-day trade meeting between US-China which at first seemed promising, though sticking points remain on issues such as IP. DXY kicked off the week on the 96.000 handle and reached highs of 96.159, however a plethora of Fed speaks sent the index lower to test 95.000 to the downside at one point. The most notable move coincided with comments from non-voter Bostic who floated the idea of a rate cut if downside risk all come to bear, thought Chair Powell and Vice Chair Clarida aided the decent of the buck by stating the Central Bank can be patient and flexible when it comes tightening. Fed aside, the US Government poised to be shut for a longest in the last 43 years as President Trump fails to accumulate the funding from the Democrats for the Southern border wall, and it’s worth noting US loses 0.1% of GDP for every week the Government is shut. Shortly after the Wall St. open on Friday, FX markets experience a bout of Dollar demand wherein DXY reclaimed 95.500 to the upside and rose as high as 95.765 at one point.

* GBP: Tumultuous week for the GBP and the UK Government after double-defeat in the House of Commons in the form of the Finance Bill (restricting Government tax power in the event of a no-deal Brexit) and Business Motion (restricting the timeframe for an alternative proposal if the PM loses the meaningful vote). Cable started the week around 1.2730 and visited (but failed to close above) 1.2800 for three out of five days (so far). Although the weekly high of 1.2850 was fuelled by reports of a potential delay to the Brexit date, this was later dismissed by a UK PM May spokeswoman as Cable retreated from the highs. Meanwhile on the data front, the Pound largely shrugged the release of the in-line UK monthly GDP and mixed industrial output as traders eye next week’s meaningful vote to shed some uncertainty surrounding Brexit.

* EUR: Overall a positive week for the EUR, albeit largely due to the decline of the buck as the single currency only appreciated from its weekly open at 1.1390 to reach highs of 1.1570 at one point. Earlier in the week, the EUR was relatively unfazed by the release of the ECB Minutes and Eurozone unemployment, though Friday saw volatile trade in the EUR/USD as most of the session saw the pair above 1.1500, though a sudden bout of dollar strength sent the pair down through its 50 DMA at 1.1477 to levels just shy if 1.1450.

* JPY: Not the most eventful week for the Yen as US-Sino trade talks at the start of the week unwound risk premium in the currency in which USD/JPY made an attempt at reclaiming the 109.00 handle to the upside. However, after a third day of dialogue and no mention of development in key sticking points (alongside a pullback in the USD), the currency pair fell back to sub-108.00 levels at one point. Overall, given the recent Dollar demand, USD/JPY is poised to end the week little changed.

* AUD, NZD, CNY: Notably the outperformers with the antipodeans on course to close the week with gains in excess of a percent vs. the buck, while the CNY is poised for its best week since 2005 with aid from the dovish Fed and a sub-6.80 PBOC fix. Upside in the AUD and NZD was mostly due to tailwinds from its Chinese counterpart alongside supportive price action in the commodities complex.

* CAD, NOK: Both beneficiaries of the rising oil prices with CAD covering further ground below 1.3400 against the buck, while the Crown took out 9.800 to the downside vs the EUR as Brent crude is set to end the week with gains in excess of 5%. The Loonie was also swayed by the BoC rate decisions which USD/CAD initially saw a dovish reaction and rose to levels just shy of 1.3250 as the Central Bank cut its growth and inflation forecasts, although this was expected. The currency pair then headed lower in a hawkish move to a low print of 1.3180 in light of the of BoC noting that rates will rise “over time” into a neutral range depending on oil market and trade developments, in turn maintaining their tightening bias.

* WEEK AHEAD: Monday: Eurozone Industrial Production, Chinese Trade Balance. Tuesday: Brexit Meaningful Vote, US PPI, New Zealand GDT Auction, Indonesian Interest Rate Decision, Japan Machinery Orders. Wednesday: Fed's Beige Book, UK CPI, US Retail Sales, NAHB Housing Market Index. Thursday: Eurozone CPI (Final), US Building Permits & Philly Fed, Japan CPI. Friday: South Korea Interest Rate Decision, UK Retail Sales, Canada CPI, US Industrial Production & Uni of Mich. Click here to read full preview.

Fixed Income: US 10yr futures hit 122-00; Gilts underperform on mixed Article 50 reports
content:
USTs were unreactive to a US CPI release which came in essentially in line with expectations on all inflation figures, with a beat on the MM real weekly earnings figure, but have caught a mild bid in recent trade which has seen 10yr futures hit 122-00. The action remains in the belly of the curve ahead of a thin schedule with traders mindful of any updates on the trade front or on the Government shutdown, which has now run into its 21st day. 

10-year Gilt futures turned on their heels to trade in negative territory after suggestions (which were later refuted) that the UK is not set to leave the EU on March 29th due to legislative factors rather than Brexit opposition. The UK benchmark failed to regain composure following Governmental denial of the fact, with Gilts and Bunds now on contrasting courses after having traded in lockstep at the start of the session. 10-year Gilt futures are now trading just above the 123.00 handle with technical traders eyeing the 122.66 21st December low level to the downside as support. Bunds remain in positive territory and are stagnant around the 164.50 area. BTPs remain the European outperformer with the Italian benchmark stable above 126.70.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 11th January 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • NETFLIX (NFLX) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT UBS
  • PG&E (PCG) – The utilities co. has been downgraded again, with Moody’s cutting its bonds to junk rating
  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The video game developer has given full publishing rights for the Destiny franchise to Bungie

11th January 2019

Earnings

  • Infosys (INFY) reports Q3 EPS USD 0.12 vs. Exp. USD 0.13, revenue USD 2.99bln vs. Exp. USD 2.95bln. Announces a USD 1.2bln share buyback programme. (Newswires)
  • Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) reports Q4 EPS USD -0.06 vs. Exp. USD 0.26, revenue USD 806.6mln vs. Exp. USD 1.02bln. Announces USD 500mln share repurchase. (Newswires)
  • Synnex (SNX) reports Q4 Adj. EPS USD 3.65 vs. Exp. USD 3.09, revenue USD 5.62bln vs. Exp. USD 5.43B. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The co. is planning to launch three new iPhones this year including a high-end one with a triple rear camera, and an iPhone XR successor with a dual-camera. (WSJ)
  • Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) – Fox will not be bidding for the regional sports networks that Disney may be selling. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The investment bank could be facing fines worth USD 5bln for its 1MDB fund scandal. (NYPost)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker’s CFO said the PC market has “stabilised itself” and spoke positively on the data centre business as well as the co.’s involvement in autonomous vehicles. (CNBC)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The conglomerate has raised prices on two dozen medicines in the US. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan (JPM) – The bank is raising its bonus pool by 3% for 2018. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Accenture (ACN) -  The tech consulting firm’s CEO and Chairman Nanterme is to step down due to health reasons with Rowland appointed as interim CEO; affirms outlook for 2019 and Q2. (Newswires)
  • Altria (MO) – The FDA is initiating a study into young people and their addiction to vaping; this comes after the co. recently acquired a stake in e-cigarette producer JUUL Labs. (NBC)
  • AT&T (T) – The telecoms giant will stop selling customer location data to third parties after facing pressure from the federal government. (Washington Post)
  • Ford (F) – The German Economy Minister is in talks with the automaker over its plans to cut jobs in Europe. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM), Tesla (TSLA) – GM has announced a new luxury electric car model under its Cadillac unit, yet to hear more details. (Newswires)
  • L3 (LLL), Harris (HRS) – The DOJ has requested additional information from the two defence names ahead of their merger, they still expect the deal to close by mid-2019. (Newswires)
  • Lennar (LEN) – The homebuilder has announced a USD 1bln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Newmont (NEM) – The miner cut 120 jobs at its Nevada gold mining operations. (Newswires)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The beverage co. appointed its CEO Ramon Laguarta as Chairman of the Board. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The utilities co. has been downgraded again, with Moody’s cutting its bonds to junk rating. (Newswires)
  • PVH Corp. (PVH) – The apparel co. raises Q4 Adj. EPS view to at least USD 1.75 from USD 1.58-1.60 vs. Exp. USD 1.60, sees Q4 revenue at least USD 2.4bln vs. Exp. USD 2.4bln. Its Calvin Klein unit announced strategic changes too. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – Users of the social media platform in China are facing detention and threats under the government’s new censorship push. (NY Times)
  • United Airlines (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) – Over 50,000 flight attendants from the two airlines have sent a letter to US leaders requesting an end to the government shutdown. (SVBJ)

NASDAQ

  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The video game developer has given full publishing rights for the Destiny franchise to Bungie. (Newswires)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant is being sued by its shareholders, who claim it had breached its duty to investors by approving big exit packages for former executives, involved in sexual misconduct, without consulting shareholders. (Verge)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailers Dash device has been determined as illegal in Germany, which claims the device doesn’t provide customers with enough product information. Elsewhere, Verge reports that the co.’s smart doorbell, Ring, allowed employees to access customer videos. (Newswires/Verge)
  • Maxim Integrated (MXIM) – The electric circuit producer’s CFO Bruce Kiddoo is to retire in H2 2019. (Newswires)
  • Social Media (TWTR, FB) – Social media co.s are looking to fight back against new measures from the Indian government that would require them to self-regulate all content. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Huawei – Polish authorities have arrested a sales director for the tech co., claiming he spied on the Chinese government’s behalf, who say the arrest is linked to just the employee and not the co. itself. (WSJ)

BROKER MOVES

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th January 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices are mixed [Euro Stoxx 50 Unch], having pared back some of the initial gains from the open
  • DXY on the backfoot further below 95.500 as the Fed signalled a more patient approach ahead of the US CPI release
  • GBP spiked higher on reports of possible Brexit date, though these reports were later dismissed by a PM May spokesperson
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, Real Weekly Earnings, Baker Hughes rig count

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher following the 5th consecutive session of gains on Wall Street as global sentiment remained underpined by perceptions of a more patient Fed approach. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were mixed with the initial upside in Australia clouded by weakness in the key financials and mining related sectors, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it coat-tailed on the recent USD/JPY moves. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) conformed to the overall positive risk tone following the recent trade-related optimism with Vice Premier Liu He said to possibly visit the US later this month and amid hopes of further supportive measures as China may adopt more tax cuts for the manufacturing sector. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre on profit taking following recent gains and with demand also limited by the upside in riskier assets.

China is reportedly to set a lower 2019 GDP growth target of between 6.0%-6.5%. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 410bln vs. CNY 320bln drain last week. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7909 (Prev. 6.8106)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there is a plan for Chinese Vice Premier Liu He to visit later this month, while reports later noted that trade talks on January 30th-31st although sources added that the US government shutdown could delay the scheduled visit. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said he will most likely declare an emergency if there is no border deal but added should be able to make a deal with Congress, while there were earlier reports that US President Trump had been briefed regarding plan to use Army Corps of Engineers funding to border wall construction. Also commented that he has the absolute right to declare a national emergency and is not doing it yet but will do if shutdown carries on. (Newswires/NBC/Twitter)

Fed's Vice Chair Clarida (voter, neutral) said Fed can be patient assessing how to adjust policy as data evolves this year and that monetary policy is not on a preset course, while he added they will not hesitate to make changes to strategy of shedding assets. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

Brexit is looking increasingly likely to be delayed beyond March 29th amid a backlog of essential bills, according to Cabinet Ministers cited by the Evening Standard. (Evening Standard) However, this has been dismissed by a UK PM May spokesperson. (Newswires)

UK PM May launched an appeal to Britain’s biggest unions last night in an attempt to win Labour support for her Brexit deal. (Times)

Leading Brexiteer and former Brexit Minister Steve Baker is planning to publish a new Brexit deal proposal which intends to take a tougher line with Brussels. Another former minister told the newspaper that serving ministers may stand down to vote against the PM’s Brexit deal. (The Guardian)

UK Works and Pensions Minister Rudd says a no-deal Brexit will not be good for the UK and she will work with colleagues to avoid it; adding that she is committed to alternatives. (Newswires)

EU Commission President Juncker still hopes a deal can be done on Brexit, as a no deal would be a disaster. (Newswires)

BBC's Katya Adler tweets, there is talk of a Juncker/Tusk letter by Monday setting out the reassurances on the backstop, although this is not confirmed. (Twitter)

ECB's Nowotny (Hawk) says EZ growth rates will be slower but will stay in positive territory, adding that Germany will likely have a very low growth rate in Q4. (Newswires)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Nov) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.10% (Prev. 0.10%)

UK GDP Estimate YY (Nov) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.30% (Prev. 1.50%)

UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Nov) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.30% (Prev. 0.40%)

Japanese PM Abe, after talks with UK PM May, has stated that the whole world wants to avoid a no-deal Brexit and has offered his deepest respect for the work she has done with the EU. (Newswires)

Confederation of British Industry expects a no-deal Brexit to shrink UK GDP by as much as 8%. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said the economy is not heading towards recession and that the government mulling additional fiscal measures to support growth. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Russian Foreign Ministry says it has the impression that the US would like to remain in Syria despite withdrawing troops. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed [Euro Stoxx 50 Unch], having pared back some of the initial gains from the open. Some initial outperformance was seen in the FTSE 100 (+0.1%) which is lead by strong performances in UK housing names after the sector was upgraded by BAML, with Persimmon (+4.4%), Taylor Wimpey (+4.8%) and Barratt Development (+2.6%) at the top of the index, however, the index was later pressured on currency effects as Sterling whipsawed on Brexit developments. Sectors are similarly in the green with some slight outperformance seen in energy names. Other notable movers include, Richemont (+2.3%) after the Co’s Q3 revenue of EUR 3.92bln was in line with the expected EUR 3.93bln and posting a 5% rise in constant currency sales for the October-December period. Meanwhile, Suez (-3.1%), Veolia (-2.6%) and Sage Group (-2.6%) are all in the red after being downgraded.

FX

DXY – Choppy session for the index but ultimately on the backfoot after losing the 95.500 level in early Asia-Pac trade as the Fed signalled a more patient approach ahead of the US CPI release later today. Both Fed Chair Powell and Vice Chair Clarida noted the Central Bank has the ability to be patient and flexible on rates given the State-side inflation data. As such the DXY fell to an overnight session low of 95.322 (vs. high of 95.508) and currently hovers around the middle of the range with US CPI in sight. Lloyds notes that the sharp decline in energy will likely weight on the headline CPI as they forecast a fall to 1.9% from 2.2%, though they expect the core figure to remain steady at 2.2%.

AUD,NZD, CNY, CAD – The marked outperformers and major beneficiaries as the USD/CNY is poised for its best week since 2005 with aid from the dovish Fed and a sub-6.80 PBoC fix. AUD/USD currently resides north of 0.7200 (vs. low of 0.7183) and reached levels last seen mid-December as optimistic Australian retail sales also underpinned the Aussie currency. Meanwhile, the Kiwi stands at the G10 leader as tailwind from its antipodean counterpart boosted the NZD/USD above its 50 and 200 DMA at 0.6786 and 0.6799 respectively to test 0.6840 to the upside, with the DMAs also set to form a golden cross. Finally, the Loonie is on the front foot as it reaps its reward from the declining greenback and the rising oil price with USD/CAD now below 1.3200 (vs. high of 1.3245) ahead of its 100 DMA at 1.3169.

GBP,EUR, JPY – All taking advantage of the receding dollar with the Pound spiking higher on reports by the Evening Standard that the Brexit date is to be delayed beyond March 29th amid a backlog of essential bills, though this was later dismissed by a PM May spokesperson. As such Cable briefly reclaimed the 1.2800 handle before hitting psychological resistance at 1.2850 ahead of its 100 DMA at 1.2892, this move was then paired back to sub-1.2800 levels as the pair stabilised around 1.2780. Subsequently EUR/GBP fell through 0.9000 past its 50, 100 and 200 HMAs before touching support at 0.8980, this move was short-lived due to the denial from the spokesperson with the pair now hovering on either side of 0.9000. Before the Evening Standard report, the Pound was largely unmoved by the in-line monthly GDP figures and mixed output data as traders remain cautious of political developments with the meaningful vote taking place on January 15th, though there were unconfirmed reports that EU’s Tusk and Juncker may send PM May a letter of assurances regarding the NI backstop by Monday. Elsewhere, EUR/USD reclaimed the 1.1500 handle and resides close to its 50 HMA at 1.1522. Option expiries for the single currency are in focus today with 3bln of strikes rolling off at 1.1500-10 and 1bln at 1.1550. It is also worth noting that the Bank of France maintained the country’s Q4 GDP forecast at 0.2% despite the domestic turmoil from the Yellow Vest protests. Meanwhile the Yen is relatively docile in regards to risk-flow and largely dominated by the buck with USD/JPY trades within a tight 108.24-47 range.

FIXED INCOME

EU Fixed income assets have kicked off the session in the green ahead of upcoming key risk events. Gilts were essentially unreactive to GDP data that came in essentially in line with expectations, whilst the output data was mixed, and remain mindful of developments in Westminster ahead of next week’s meaningful vote. The UK benchmark is hanging around the high print of the day at 123.51 with traders eying yesterday’s high print of 123.70 as the next level of resistance. 10-year Bund futures are probing the 164.50 level to the upside and 2s10s are seeing some bull flattening. BTPs are the days outperformer and trading with gains of over 30-ticks as the Italian benchmark finds a firm footing above the 126.80 level.

UST futures are also higher across the curve with the majority of the action in the belly of the curve after yesterday’s dovish Fed commentary from Fed’s Clarida alongside President Trump’s comments that he would declare an emergency should no border wall deal emerge and ahead of US CPI later in the day. On the supply side, yesterday’s 30yr auction had a poor showing with the b/c printing 2.19x vs. 2.31 prev. 

COMMODITIES 

Brent (+0.6%) and WTI (+0.8%) prices are in the green benefiting from the positive sentiment seen across US and Asian sessions after dovish comments from multiple Fed speakers. Russian oil output for January 1st-10th has dropped to 11.38mln BPD from 11.45mln BPD in December; additionally, Russian Energy Minister Novak is reportedly planning to attend the upcoming January 22nd-25th Davos summit.

Gold (+0.5%) prices are just shy of USD 1295.2/oz, the sessions high, following dovish comments from the Fed applying downward pressure to the dollar. Copper prices are similarly higher on the positive market sentiment, in particular that Chinese Vice Premier He is to visit the US later on in the month. Elsewhere, India’s steel ministry is refusing to back down on tougher import rules on steel, pressuring automakers into using local steel instead.

BofAML Weekly Flow report: Buy Risk, Own Credit, Rent Cyclicals
content:
Asset Class Flows:

  • Equities: biggest inflows in 11 weeks $6.2bn ($3.8bn ETF inflows, $2.4bn mutual fund inflows)
  • Bonds: biggest inflows in 39 weeks ($7.2bn)
  • Precious metals: 5th week of inflows ($1.1bn)

Fixed Income Flows:

  • IG bond fund outflows 16 of past 17 weeks ($1.4bn)
  • HY bond inflows ($1.5bn)
  • EM debt inflows biggest in 12 months ($2.4bn)
  • Large Muni fund inflows ($1.1bn)
  • 14th week of Govt/Tsy inflows ($3.6bn)
  • 18th week of TIPS outflows ($0.4bn)
  • 8th week of Bank loan fund outflows ($0.4bn)

Equity Flows:

  • US: small outflows ($0.6bn)
  • Japan: small inflows ($0.8bn)
  • Europe: outflows 43 of past 44 weeks ($0.1bn)
  • EM: 13th week of inflows ($2.4bn)
  • By style: inflows US growth ($2.1bn), US large cap ($1.8bn), US small cap ($0.3bn); outflows US value ($0.7bn)
  • By sector: inflows healthcare ($0.2bn), energy ($0.1bn), real estate ($0.1bn); outflows materials ($0.2bn), utilities ($0.2bn), consumer ($0.5bn), tech ($0.6bn), financials ($1.5bn)

Key takeaways:

  • Buy risk: Positioning & Policy makers have capitulated; Profit capitulation underway
  • Own "credit" theme: rates have peaked, corporate bond yields attractive; 3% "big top" in Treasury yields negative for banks
  • Rent "cyclical" theme: German stocks at 50-year lows relative to US but Asian exports/global PMIs yet to trough

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th January 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher following the 5th consecutive session of gains on Wall Street as global sentiment remained underpinned by perceptions of a more patient Fed approach. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were mixed with the initial upside in Australia clouded by weakness in the key financials and mining related sectors, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it coat-tailed on the recent USD/JPY moves. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) conformed to the overall positive risk tone following the recent trade-related optimism with Vice Premier Liu He said to possibly visit the US later this month and amid hopes of further supportive measures as China may adopt more tax cuts for the manufacturing sector.

FTSE

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co and Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) are stockpiling packet and tinned food in preparation for a no-deal Brexit. (The Guardian)

UK Banks – The UK Government has rejected calls to change business lending laws despite a string of scandals in the sector from lenders including Llyods-HBOS, a subsidiary of Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN), and RBS (RBS LN). (FT)

UK Utility Names – A UK regulator has confirmed that a possible “significant” increase to the energy price cap is likely to be announced within weeks despite the decline in wholesale costs. (The Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Siemens (SIE GY) – Co and Alstom (ALO FP) are discussing additional divestment with the European Commission, in order to gain approval for their joint Franco-German rail champion plan. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) -  Co is offshoring around 60 accounting positions to Mumbai from Florida, in order to reduce costs. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co are seeking damages from former managers dismissed due to their involvement in the diesel emissions scandal which has cost the Co up to USD 30bln. (Handelsblatt)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – A US appeals court has ruled that they will not hold a review for EPA registration of Dicamba Herbicide. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hella (HLE GY) – Co have confirmed their current outlook. Continued positive development is expected for current FY 2018/19, EBIT of EUR 537mln vs. Prev. EUR 290mln. Adjusted EBIT EUR 302mln, increase of 5.5%. (Newswires)

Kuka (KU2 GY) – Co lower their 2018 sales revenue guidance to around EUR 3.2bln. Co lowered their 2018 EBIT-margin guidance to around 3%. Co states the guidance adjustment is due to a 2018 Q4 stronger slowdown in automotive and electronic industry, alongside uncertainties in the Chinese automation market. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SUEDZUCKER (SZU GY) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) – Former Chairman Ghosn has been indicted by Tokyo prosecutors on two new charges of financial misconduct. Ghosn’s former Nissan board member Kelly for allegedly understating Ghosn’s income in financial statements for 3 fiscal years through to March 2018. (Newswires)

Saint Gobain (SGO FP) – Co says it sold its regional glass business Glassolutions Norway and Sweden to Mimir Invest. (Newswires)

Accor (AC FP) – Co. has lifted their offer for Orbis to PLN 95/shr from a prev. offer of PLN 87/shr. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th January 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher following the 5th consecutive session of gains on Wall Street
  • In FX markets, the DXY pared some of the prior day’s gains which has provided some reprieve for its major counterparts across the pond
  • Fed Chair Powell repeated that the Fed has the ability to be patient given the inflation data and has the ability to be patient and flexible rates
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK GDP & Production, US CPI, Real Weekly Earnings, Baker Hughes, ECB’s Mersch, Nowotny & Makuch, supply from Italy

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher following the 5th consecutive session of gains on Wall Street as global sentiment remained underpinned by perceptions of a more patient Fed approach. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were mixed with the initial upside in Australia clouded by weakness in the key financials and mining related sectors, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it coat-tailed on the recent USD/JPY moves. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) conformed to the overall positive risk tone following the recent trade-related optimism with Vice Premier Liu He said to possibly visit the US later this month and amid hopes of further supportive measures as China may adopt more tax cuts for the manufacturing sector. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre on profit taking following recent gains and with demand also limited by the upside in riskier assets.

China is reportedly to set a lower 2019 GDP growth target of between 6.0%-6.5%. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 410bln vs. CNY 320bln drain last week. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7909 (Prev. 6.8106)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there is a plan for Chinese Vice Premier Liu He to visit later this month, while reports later noted that trade talks on January 30th-31st although sources added that the US government shutdown could delay the scheduled visit. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

UK PM May launched an appeal to Britain’s biggest unions last night in an attempt to win Labour support for her Brexit deal. (Times)

Leading Brexiteer and former Brexit Minister Steve Baker is planning to publish a new Brexit deal proposal which intends to take a tougher line with Brussels. Another former minister told the newspaper that serving ministers may stand down to vote against the PM’s Brexit deal. (The Guardian)

Japanese PM Abe, after talks with UK PM May, has stated that the whole world wants to avoid a no-deal Brexit and has offered his deepest respect for the work she has done with the EU. (Newswires)

Confederation of British Industry expects a no-deal Brexit to shrink UK GDP by as much as 8%. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said the economy is not heading towards recession and that the government mulling additional fiscal measures to support growth. (Newswires)

EU Trade Commissioner Malmstrom said the EU would not accept quotas on car exports to the US. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY pared some of the prior day’s gains which has provided some reprieve for its major counterparts across the pond in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD also found support around the 1.1500 and 1.2750 levels respectively. The softer greenback also capped some of the risk-fuelled advances in USD/JPY, while antipodeans were underpinned by their high-beta status, better than expected Australian Retail Sales data and as CNH continued to firm in which USD/CNH slipped below 6.7500 after the PBoC adjusted the fix to its strongest since late July.

Australian Retail Sales (Nov) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly underpinned amid a softer greenback and the predominantly positive risk appetite which underpinned copper prices, while gold approached closer towards the USD 1300/oz level in the wake of the plethora of dovish rhetoric this week from the Fed. Conversely, WTI crude futures were flat near this week’s highs as prices took a breather from the recent rally above the USD 52.00/bbl.

US

The Treasury curve bear-steepened modestly on Thursday, with 2s30s and 5s30s wider by 4bps at settlement. The US auction of 30-year bonds was grim, tailing by 1.1bps, and adding pressure to the long-end, not helped by corporate supply. Cover was weaker, directs took the largest takedown since Dec 2014, indirects the smallest since November 2016. Treasuries settled unchanged at 121-23.

US President Trump said he will most likely declare an emergency if there is no border deal but added should be able to make a deal with Congress, while there were earlier reports that US President Trump had been briefed regarding plan to use Army Corps of Engineers funding to border wall construction. Furthermore, President Trump tweeted he is cancelling his trip to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland due to the Democrats and also commented that he has the absolute right to declare a national emergency and is not doing it yet but will do if shutdown carries on. (Newswires/NBC/Twitter)

Fed Chair Powell repeated that the Fed has the ability to be patient given the inflation data and has the ability to be patient and flexible on rates, while he also commented that there is no preset path for rates and that markets are pricing in a more pessimistic view than is apparent in data. Furthermore, Powell also commented that he doesn't know what the ideal level to let the balance sheet shrink to but will be "substantially" smaller. (Newswires)

Fed's Vice Chair Clarida (voter, neutral) said Fed can be patient assessing how to adjust policy as data evolves this year and that monetary policy is not on a preset course, while he added they will not hesitate to make changes to strategy of shedding assets. (Newswires)
 

Fed's Bullard (voter, dove) said the Fed is sufficiently pre-emptive on inflation and should be moderate in normalising policy, while he added that he is moderately concerned the global slowdown will worsen. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (voter, dove) said FOMC can easily assess the data for six months before lifting rates. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (voter, dove) reiterated his opposition to further rate hikes and warned there could be uncounted slack in the US labour market. (Newswires)

Asia equity markets are mostly positive following the 5th consecutive win streak by their counterparts on Wall Street as global sentiment remains underpinned by perceptions of a more patient Fed approach. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) are mixed with the initial upside in Australia clouded by weakness in the key financials and mining related sectors, while the Japanese benchmark outperforms as it coat-tailed on the recent USD/JPY moves. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) conform to the overall risk tone following the recent trade-related optimism with Vice Premier Liu He said to possibly visit the US later this month and amid hopes of further supportive measures as China may adopt more tax cuts for the manufacturing sector.

In FX markets, the greenback has started to pare the prior day’s rebound which has provided some reprieve for its major counterparts across the pond, with EUR/USD and GBP/USD also finding support around the 1.1500 and 1.2750 levels respectively. The softer greenback has also begun to pare back some of the risk-fuelled advances in USD/JPY, while antipodeans are mildly underpinned by their high-beta status and following better than expected Australian Retail Sales, although resistance at the 0.7200 handle has restricted upside for AUD/USD. CNH has continued to firm with USD/CNH now below 6.7700 after the reference rate setting in which the PBoC adjusted the fix to its strongest since late July.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lacklustre on profit taking following recent gains and with demand also limited by the upside in riskier assets.
